work.p: This manuscript demonstrates that Whitman was considering a "Poem of the Stars" and "Astronomy," which may have resulted in "When I Heard the Learn'd Astronomer," a poem first published in 1865 in Drum-Taps. Whitman retained this title in all printings of this poem.

Whitman's notes on this manuscript considering a "Poem of Chemistry" may have resulted in "This Compost," a poem first published in the 1856 edition of Leaves of Grass under the title "Poem of Wonder at The Resurrection of The Wheat," and as "Leaves of Grass" No. 4 in the 1860 Leaves of Grass. The poem was titled "This Compost" in 1867 and in all subsequent editions.

The manuscript notes suggesting a "Poem of Musicians" may have resulted in "Proud Music of the Storm," first published as "Proud Music of the Sea-Storm" in the Atlantic Monthly in February, 1869. The poem took its final title, "Proud Music of the Storm," in 1871 in Passage to India.

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: This manuscript was likely composed before 1860, for that was a period when Whitman was teeming with ideas for poems. The repetition of "Poem of" also suggests a composition date near the 1856 edition of Leaves of Grass, in which each poem begins with the words "Poem of." Additionally, the distinctive blue paper resembles that of other manuscripts dated about 1859 (on this last point, see Edward F. Grier, ed., Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts [New York: New York University Press, 1984], 4: 1364 headnote). An unusual quality of this manuscript is the red mark, quite like a check mark, that appears on few Whitman manuscripts.

list.head: Poems identifying the different branches of the Sciences, as for instance,
list.item:
Poem of The Stars
? Astronomy
? Suns, planets ? & moons

Poem of Geology ? (not a good word)
? the processes of The Earth

Poem of Arithmetic
Mathematics
Calculation
Figures—Exactitude—
Poem of Musicians tenor, soprano, baritone, basso,
